intro: Carum heyneanum, commonly known as wild chervil, is a herbaceous plant native to parts of Asia and Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and thrives in moist, temperate climates. Its aromatic leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. The fruit is a dry, two-lobed schizocarp that disperses seeds when mature.
